author: George Orwell
description: A dystopian novel about a totalitarian regime that controls every aspect of human life.
pre_questions: What do you understand by totalitarianism?
How do you think constant surveillance affects individual freedom?
Is it possible that truth is relative?
post_questions: How did your perspective on power change after reading the book?

Which character impacted you the most and why?
author_bio: George Orwell (1903-1950) was a British writer known for his dystopian novels that criticize totalitarianism. '1984' is his most iconic masterpiece that warns about the dangers of extreme authoritarianism.

title: Don Quixote
author: Miguel de Cervantes
description: The adventures of Don Quixote, a knight who loses his mind and sets out on imaginary adventures.
pre_questions: What do you know about the literature of knight-errantry?
What is the difference between fantasy and reality?
Do you think dreaming is important in life?
post_questions: What was Cervantes' purpose in writing this book?
How does the character of Sancho complement Don Quixote?
What lesson about reality vs. dreams did you take from the book?
author_bio: Miguel de Cervantes (1547-1616) was a Spanish writer who revolutionized literature. 'Don Quixote' is considered one of the first modern novels and is widely recognized as a masterpiece of world literature.

title: Pride and Prejudice
author: Jane Austen
description: A story of romance and social analysis in nineteenth-century England where Elizabeth Bennet defies conventions.
pre_questions: What role do prejudices play in our relationships?
How has the concept of marriage changed throughout history?
Is it possible to truly know someone at first sight?
post_questions: How did the relationship between Elizabeth and Darcy evolve?
What social criticism does Austen make of her era's society?
Which secondary character seemed most memorable to you?
author_bio: Jane Austen (1775-1817) was an English novelist who wrote with keen insight about women's lives in her time. Her works are recognized for their wit, irony, and sharp social commentary.

title: The Lord of the Rings
author: J.R.R. Tolkien
description: An epic fantasy about the battle between good and evil in the imaginary world of Middle-earth.
pre_questions: What characteristics define a true hero?
How does power influence people?
Do you believe in friendship as a transformative force?
post_questions: How was friendship crucial to Frodo's mission?
What did you learn about leadership from Aragorn?
How did the temptation of power affect different characters?
author_bio: J.R.R. Tolkien (1892-1973) was a British philologist and author who created Middle-earth. His pioneering works in fantasy literature have inspired generations of readers and set the standards for the genre.

title: Crime and Punishment
author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
description: A deep analysis of the psychology of a student who commits a crime and grapples with guilt and redemption.
pre_questions: Is it justifiable to commit a crime for a greater cause?
How are guilt and conscience related?
Can someone truly escape from their actions?
post_questions: How did Raskolnikov's perception of his crime evolve?

What reflection did this book leave you with about morality and justice?
author_bio: Fyodor Dostoevsky (1821-1881) was a Russian writer who explored profound themes of human psychology, religion, and morality. His novels are considered among the most important in world literature.

title: Jane Eyre
author: Charlotte Brontë
description: The story of an independent woman who fights for her freedom and dignity in Victorian society.
pre_questions: What does independence mean for a woman in the Victorian era?
How does childhood influence adult life?
Is it possible to love without losing your own identity?
post_questions: How does Jane become a symbol of feminism?

author_bio: Charlotte Brontë (1816-1855) was a British author who wrote under a male pseudonym. 'Jane Eyre' is revolutionary for its strong and independent female protagonist, far ahead of its time.

title: One Hundred Years of Solitude
author: Gabriel García Márquez
description: The multigenerational saga of the Buendía family in the fictional town of Macondo, blending magical realism with reality.
pre_questions: How can magic be a literary tool?
What is destiny and are we predestined?
How does solitude define people?
post_questions: How does the style of magical realism enrich the narrative?

author_bio: Gabriel García Márquez (1927-2014) was a Colombian writer and pioneer of magical realism. Winner of the Nobel Prize in Literature, his work has revolutionized Latin American and world fiction.

title: The Metamorphosis
author: Franz Kafka

author_bio: Franz Kafka (1883-1924) was a Czech writer whose works explore alienation and the absurdity of modern existence. His work has profoundly influenced twentieth-century literature.

title: The Great Gatsby

author_bio: F. Scott Fitzgerald (1896-1940) was an American writer who captured the essence of the Jazz Age. 'The Great Gatsby' is considered one of the most important novels in American literature.

title: Little Women

author_bio: Louisa May Alcott (1832-1888) was an American author known for her stories about independent young women. 'Little Women' remains a beloved novel that inspires readers of all ages.
